results.title: A Good Eye for Story
results.credit_line:
Filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)
Equipment provided by Panavision Australia
Colour by Matt Fezz
Special thanks to CAAMA Productions
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 3:06 min
results.brief_description: Dylan River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.
results.headline_credit_for_label:
filmed in Mbantua (Alice Springs)

Equipment provided by Panavision Australia

Colour by Matt Fezz
results.description:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

River’s film A Good Eye for Story is a quirky and intimate picture looking at the framework for which he shares his ideas and the impact that his family, community and the landscape around Alice Springs have had on his growing practice as a storyteller.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River
description_for_label:
Dylan River is a filmmaker who shares stories from his unique perspective as a Kaytetye man. River works across many roles including cinematography, directing, and writing, for web series, documentary, short film, and cinema.

“This film explores my journey over the past ten years of being behind the cinema camera. The way my eye has changed from looking at images as being formulaic to appreciating the story behind every one.” – Dylan River

results.title: The Silenced
results.credit_line:
Julie Gough
Single-channel video work
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 6:18 min
results.brief_description: In works such as The Silenced, Trawlwoolway artist Julie Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories, interrogating colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania. Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples. In works such as The Silenced Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.” – Julie Gough
description_for_label:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania. Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples. In works such as The Silenced Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.” – Julie Gough

results.title: Where the Desert Meets the Sea
results.credit_line:
Cinematography by Brad Gibb 
Edited by Ben Lane  
Special thanks to Wayne Miller
results.material_description: HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 4:12 min
results.brief_description: Shelley Ware’s film Where the Desert Meets the Sea (2020) tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.
results.description:
Shelley Ware is one of Australia’s most respected female sports presenters. She is a Yankunytjatjara, Wirangu and Kokatha woman, well known for her role on the SBS program Marngrook Footy Show. Currently, Ware hosts the AFL.com web show ‘Colour of Your Jumper.’ Ware is also an educator, and her film Where the Desert Meets the Sea tells the story of her family’s legacy that has led her to a career in AFL presenting.

“This is a story of my Country and why the game of AFL and the Koonibba Football Club are so important to me. I share the stories of my people, as a teacher and sports presenter, so that our children, can be what they see.” – Shelley Ware
description_for_label:

results.title: BeDevil
results.creator_credit: Tracey Moffatt, Carol Hughes, Anthony Buckley and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description: BeDevil is an astounding work of Australian cinema which combines iconography drawn from Aboriginal culture and mythology, urban Australia, and popular culture. Comprising three ghost stories, all of which deal with the nature of memory and loss, this film playfully subverts the conventional linkings between aboriginality and spirituality. In “Mr. Chuck” the ghost of a US soldier haunts a billabong. In “Choo Choo Choo Choo” Ruby, (played by director Tracey Moffatt), and her family are haunted by an invisible train. In the final story, “Lovin’ The Spin I’m In”, a grieving Islander mother and her Greek-Australian neighbours are under the spell of the ghostly lovers, Bebe and Minnie. Drawing from influences that span across Aboriginal culture, American and European film, television and popular culture, “BeDevil” announces the birth of a new kind of Australian cinema: both indigenous and multicultural; mystical and sophisticated; innovative and pleasurable. The intoxicating cinematography is by Academy-award winning Geoff Burton and the music score is by Carl Vine. Visually stunning and metaphorically rich, this is a wonderful film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tracey Moffatt, Carol Hughes, Anthony Buckley and Southern Star Entertainment

results.title: Beard and bass
results.brief_description: An experimental short film about a bearded young man and a double bass. Clasping the instrument he tries to cross a street. Suddenly his attention is arrested by a girl whose charms he appreciates. She smiles at him and crosses the street. He stares at her and then realising suddenly that she has disappeared, he props up his double bass against the tree and disappears into the crowd. Music by George Dreyfus, edited by Peter Tammer.

results.title: The Anzac Story
results.creator_credit: ABC, Frank Hunter and George I. Malcolm
results.brief_description: This video contains two programs pertaining to the history of the Anzacs using archival footage, drawings and stills and narrated by Barry Lineham. “Prelude to glory” - Presents a brief historical overview of Captain Cook’s landings in New Zealand and Australia and the following events which took place including colonisation, the chain of British governors, a Treaty with the Maoris, Federation in Australia, and the eventual lead up to World War I. With the advent of the War came the formation of the Anzac Corps, an alliance between the Australian and New Zealand defence forces, and a commitment by the Anzacs to fight for the British Empire in a war half a world away. Shows the sailing of the first convoy, the naval battle and sinking of the German battle ship “Emden” and the arrival of the Anzacs in Egypt. “Gallipoli” - Tells the story of this ill-fated war against the Turks, the tragic mistakes, the chaos and disorganisation, and the horrendous loss of young Anzacs (10,000 soldiers) from the botched up landing on 25 April 1915 in a small bay south of Ari Burnu (renamed Anzac Cove) to the eventual evacuation of all troops in December 1915.

holdings.name: MOV file H264; ACMI Digital Access Copy - presentation

results.title: Stereoscopic viewers and cards
results.brief_description: Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.

constellations_primary.name: New ways of seeing
constellations_primary.description: The 3D worlds presented through the stereoscopic viewer are part of an ongoing fascination with immersive imagery.

results.description:
Three-dimensional images have been around for more than 180 years – they just weren’t called ‘3D’. Stereoscopic images are two separate pictures with slightly different perspectives. A stereoscopic viewer mimics how we see so that the two images converge into a single three-dimensional picture.

British inventor Charles Wheatstone discovered this process in 1838 and used a device as big as a table to make it work. Another British scientist, David Brewster, later simplified and shrank the viewer into a portable, hand-held device.

Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.

Stereoscopic viewers were popular home entertainment in the Victorian era. They let people see 3D engineering wonders, like new skyscrapers and railroads, as well as sightseeing slides from across the natural world.
